Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of actor wearing comedy mask, with erect phallus. Feet missing. Mould-made and hollow with vent at back. Soft (gypsum?) and pink paint preserved on some areas of skin and mask. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with red core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably locally produced at the ‘Naukratis Terracottas workshop’ that dates to the 3rd and 2nd century BC. Actors and masks were a common subject of terracottas in Naukratis. Other Egyptian parallels from Naukratis (BM GR1886,0401.1410) and other sites date from the 4th to the late 2nd century BC (Fischer 1994; no. 319-320, 324), and were based on earlier Classical and Hellenistic Greek examples (Bayer-Niemeier 1986; 132-6, no. 68-69, 86, 4th to 2nd century BC from Attica and Smyrna; Mollard-Besques 1963; pl. 171.g, Myrina no. 99, late 3rd century BC). Parallel from Ptoelmaic Memphis (Petrie Museum UC48548). Bayer Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen. Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen; Wasmuth. Mollard-Besques, S. 1963. Catalogue raisonnédes figurines et reliefs en terre-cuite Grecs et Romains II: Myrina. Paris; Musée National du Louvre.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.296) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 96, nos 325-326)
